When a mobile game makes the jump onto PC, the outcome usually falls into two categories. Either it sucks or it sucks so much that Steam have to call in extra employees to sit on the edges of the storefront, lest it collapses in on itself like a neutron star and murders us all.

Silver Bullet: Prometheus isn't a horrible game which makes it all the more unfortunate that it turns out to be a victim of its prior Android/iOS mechanics. Originally, the game was played by tapping enemies for your run-of-the-mill-foxy-lady-with-an-attitude protagonist to shoot, rather than giving you independent control of the gunplay. This has been switched out in favour of just right-clicking in the general area of whatever zombie, drug-dealer or robot ghost samurai you're trying to kill, making it nearly impossible to single enemies out.

While that makes it mind-numbingly simple to navigate the first half of the game (honestly, closing your eyes and clicking the screen would yield very similar results), the slapdash targeting becomes frustrating in boss battles, especially when you come up against mechanoid terror spiders that fire an onslaught of missiles at you that need shooting down.

Visually, Silver Bullet looks lovely and the chunky arcade UI and character modelling is a big plus. There's 45 stages to plough through with objectives varying from escort, base defence and outright slaughter as well as an arena mode to level yourself up in for an in-game advantage. It just hasn't translated at all well from its point of origin. A shooter where you have precious little control over what you actually shoot. Can't recommend it sadly.

First of all, you need to know that this is a kind of an old-school. Though there is some cool features, this game is basically not so kind to players, not so speedy, not so easy. The worst thing is poor UI.

But, in my case, this game is not so bad. Actually good. I like the stylish targeting & shooting. I like the bosses that have each other characters. I like the story - some people think it is poor, as there are just dialogues without any cut scene or ilust image, but it remind me the old Metal Gear.

I'm playing the chapter 28. The half of the game was easy and predictable at first, But now there are more puzzles and it is getting more challenging. I expect this game is getting more interesting.

So, that's all. Choice is yours.
